required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Intra-Abdominal Pressure Effect on Intra-Abdominal Volume and Airway Pressures During Laparoscopy
clinical_study.official_title: Intra-Abdominal Pressure Effect on Intra-Abdominal Volume and Airway Pressures During Pneumoperitoneum Insufflation - a Patient-Level Meta-Analysis of Three Randomized Clinical Trials

brief_summary.textblock:
During pneumoperitoneum insufflation the insufflated gas increase intra-abdominal pressure. The generated pressure can lead to a different increase in volume depending on the abdominal cavity and patients' characteristics.
The primary objective is to determine the relationship between intraabdominal pressure (IAP) and intraabdominal volume (IAV) during pneumoperitoneum insufflation. The secondary objective is to determine the rate of abdominal-thoracic transmission (ATT) assessing the correlation between IAP and respiratory driving pressure (Î”PRS).

secondary_outcome.description: This is the pressure that exert a stress on the respiratory system during mechanical ventilation. It is calculated by subtracting the positive endexpiratory pressure from plateau pressure
This is the pressure in the airway during the mechanical venitilation inspiratory pause time

arm_group.description: A global cohort is built merging data from three studies

intervention.description: Before surgery pneumoperitoneum is established by insufflating gas into the abdomen. Intraabdominal pressure (IAP) is set to 15 mmHg for initial abdominal stretching and then decreased in a stepwise manner down until 8 mmHg.

study_pop.textblock: Patients undergoing pneumoperitoenum insufflation during general anesthesia and mechanical venitlation.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Enrolled one of the three studies (IPPCollapse I, II or III).
- underwent an initial insufflation procedure with a stepwise change in intraabdominal pressure to record Intraabdominal volume
- data from insufflation at 5 cmH2O of PEEP
